newsitem.title: AUSTRIA: First private tv station to hit Vienna airwaves.
newsitem.headline: First private tv station to hit Vienna airwaves.

text.p: Just two months after Austria unveiled a draft law to liberalise its television and radio markets, Vienna's first private cable television station is about to go on air.
The new station, Wien 1, is being marketed as hip, slick and on the ball, using glossy graphics and fast-paced shots to dance music in the style of MTV.
It will be available to some 800,000 of the roughly one million Viennese from April 15, via the domestic cable network Telekabel.
"Take a look -- a look at Vienna" is the Wien 1 philosophy.
"With Wien 1 we are beginning a new era in media in Vienna," Friedrich Loew, General Director of broadcasting company Elbemuehl which part owns the station, told a news conference on Thursday.

Until February Austria was considered to be pitifully backward in its media, offering just two state-owned terrestrial television channels ORF 1 and ORF 2, which often broadcast the same programme simultaneously.
The new station is owned by RTV Regional-TV Services AG, a holding in which Elbemuehl, Austrian bank BAWAG and First Austrian savings bank each have 20 percent.
Negotiations about the remaining 40 percent were continuing, but no decision had been made as to the eventual ownership structure, Loew said.
The station's total budget for 1997 is 100 million schillings ($8.3 million) with 50 million schillings set aside for advertising spending.
RTV Regional-TV Services AG has basic capital of 40 million schillings and also owns local broadcaster RTV in Lower Austria. Loew said the holding was seeking more investors.
Wien 1 will broadcast around the clock, producing three hours of new material daily, which will be repeated in stages.
The programme will feature news, entertainment, chat shows, travel and weather updates, vignettes from Vienna life, and local gossip.
"Wien 1 is a Viennese programme, exclusively oriented to Vienna, which also aims to involve Viennese citizens actively," Loew said.
The station envisages it will reach between 50,000 to 60,000 viewers daily in the first few months.

"We are targetting mainly young, educated earners and families with a good income," said Alfreda Bergmann-Fiaka, director at Telekabel. "We can only cross our fingers and hope we have not got it wrong," she added.
In 1993 the European Court of Human Rights ruled that Austria's stringent media laws violated the right to free speech.

Under the new law cable stations will not need a licence to broadcast. Media stakes will be limited to 26 percent and foreign stakes, excluding the Europe Economic Area -- comprising European Union members and some non-EU western European countries to 49 percent.
